fields.description: It would be great if there is a Project administration option to make Title and/or Objectives mandatory. This would help to prevent developers from creating reviews without enough information to know what the review was for.
fields.summary: Provide an option for  user to select review Title and/or Objectives to be mandatory field

fields.description:
If an user creates a review in a project with _[Store content|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE/Creating+a+Project]_ checked and adds changesets to it, but he/she does not get to the review summary (or leaves it prematurely), the contents of the Crucible revisions are not stored.

This happens because the content of those revisions is lazily persisted (if 'Store content' is checked on the project). They are persisted on the first ajax call to {{/loadFrxAjax}} when the review summary is shown. If the user prematurely navigates off the summary screen to another screen or does not go to the summary at all, the contents of those revisions is not stored.

Usually this is not an issue (they will be stored next time the review is opened), but if the repository becomes unavailable (stopped, disabled or deleted), the review does show {{NullPointerException}} instead.
fields.summary: Review shows NullPointerException in the review summary if the repository is unavailable (and 'Store content' is checked)

fields.description:
Allow users to change a file type within a crucible review from binary to text and vice versa. 

This does not affect the state of the file in the underlying FishEye repository. 

The impact of the potentially large files, that may result, on the Crucible UI needs to be considered.
fields.summary: Provide UI Mechanism to treat a binary file as text in a review

fields.description:
Whenever I receive a notification regarding a new review, the link that is sent to me is unreachable.  From what I can tell, a port number (9080 I believe) is being appended to the link.  Removing the port number allows me to connect to the appropriate review.

So fixing this issue should be as easy as removing the port number from the review link template.
fields.summary: Links in Crucible notifications are bad

fields.description:
If I want to highlight and copy code in Firefox, I have to do the following:

Alt + highlight text
Do a Ctrl-C + Shift
Open Notepad or Outlook, Ctrl V or right click and select Paste.
Allows you to copy from Crucible and paste it to notepad or outlook. 

If we did Ctrl+Shift+C, it won't copy and what you paste isn't what was in your clipboard previously.

If I do the same test in Chrome. I can Alt + highlight text
Do a Ctrl-C
Open Notepad or Outlook and do a Ctrl V or right click, select paste and it works.


Is this the expected behaviour in Firefox and Chrome?  Why can't I do a Ctrl C to copy text in Firefox?  I tested this with someone else and he got the same results. I've started my browser and machine and I get the same results.  Are you able to duplicate this?
fields.summary: Copy and paste problems with FireFox 3.6 under Windows

fields.description: if you left the comment box empty when the autosave kicks in, it fails (due to empty comment), and you get an error dialog box. It should not show the error dialog if comment is empty, and it should not perform autosave if there is no comment to save in the first place.
fields.summary: changeset discussion autosave fails with error dialog when no comment is entered
Allow create and delete project via REST API

fields.description: Screenhot nails it.
fields.summary: Showing only time for each changeset (not from today) on Add Content to Review screen does not make sense

fields.description:
Hi, our users would like to have the ability to have more than one reviewer list. This way when they do a review that belongs in software component "X", they could pick a "distribution list"of reviewers that is already setup for that component. Rather than having to manually edit the default list of reviews to be just the reviewers for that particular component.

Ideally, I guess you would want a drop down list that lets you select which reviewer-list you want to use for a review.

Users should be able to add/remove themselves from a reviewers list, so the project admins don't have to manage it.

Basically for large organizations this allows teams to quickly select the right reviewers.
fields.summary: quick select, customizable reviewer list

fields.description:
h3. Summary

If you change the diff view when looking at a diff in FishEye from unified to side-by-side, this seems to force the entire system to start displaying diffs side-by-side.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set your user preference to view diffs as unified.
# In FishEye for a file, set the diff view to be side by side.
# Add this file to a Crucible review. It will be viewed as side by side, regardless of the user setting.

h3. Expected Results
Behaviour should be consistent between FishEye and Crucible, either setting just for a file or setting globally. 

h3. Actual Results
Setting a diff view in FishEye overrides the user preference in Crucible
fields.summary: Changing Diff View in FishEye Applies to Crucible and Overrides User Preference

fields.description:
*Premises:*
* Crucible 2.6.4
* Perforce (P4 server: P4D/NTX86/2008.2/190934 (2009/03/05)

*Steps to replicate:*
# Create a new review.
# Add a changeset ({{"rev8"}}) with a single {{filename.cpp}} file to the review;
# Add another changeset with a later revision ({{"rev9"}}) of the same {{filename.cpp}} file to the same review;
# The review's files list (on the left) shows {{filename.cpp}} twice, once for each changeset, one below the other.
# When clicking each instance of {{filename.cpp}}, the revisions slider shows only two revisions being diffed:
## {{rev7 - rev8}} for the first instance
## {{rev8 - rev9}} for the second instance

This behavior is wrong, because only one file should be listed on the files list, and the revisions slider should display all the three revisions, i.e., {{rev7 - rev8 - rev9}}.

This happens to all browsers (FF 5, IE 9, Chrome).
No errors thrown in the logs.

Please see the images attached showing the problem.
fields.summary: File list displaying the same file twice, impacting diffs

fields.description:
Our group of 20 developers were previously actively using Crucible, and we were really happy with it. Creating code reviews was a breeze. fields.description:
I am continually vexed by this limitation. I have folks on my team for whom I wish to initiate code reviews on a case by case basis. I do not wish that they create an enormous number of reviews that I don't have time to handle, but rather that I peruse the check-ins and comment when needed.  I wish to make comments on their code, have them respond/fix and then close the review when I am satisfied. I don't want them (the author) to summarize (frankly the whole summary thing seems useless to me). I am the person reviewing, and I want to be in control of when it's marked complete.

Currently, the system actively disallows me from setting myself as a reviewer without ceding control of when the review is marked complete.

fields.description:
Uploading of patches automatically tries to anchor the patch.
For patches with ambiguous file names, uploading against a server with many large complicated SVN repos, this anchoring can take a long time.
We should:
* Set a limit on the amount of time we try to anchor the patch
* Limit paths we automatically anchor to to the "trunk", for SVN (this may/may not be possible)
* Differentiate for the user between uploading the patch and anchoring
If this fails or times out, we should:
* Go straight to allowing the user to pick a repository and path to anchor to.
fields.summary: Patch Anchoring: UI Improvements for uploading patches

fields.description:
During investigation work carried out as part of a support ticket (CRC-2833), we came across non-optimal anchoring behaviour with certain pre-commit patches.
We already feed information to Crucible in the form of a default Fisheye repo to be associated with the review project.
From what I can tell Crucible is ignoring this information and attempting to anchor the patch to all repos (possibly in alphabetical order)
I think the following is pretty reasonable set of anchoring steps to be taken by Crucible:
1. Check if patch can be anchored to default repository of project. If no path has been specified within default repo, Crucible already defaults to trunk
2. If it cannot be anchored to trunk, then alert the user to this fact and present them with a screen to the select a branch from the associated repo, or a different repo+branch altogether.

The following are the steps we took to show the problem.
# Created a new pre-commit review
# Uploaded OMS-13597.patch (attached) which is an extremely simply patch against the trunk of one of our repos (and contains full path information)
# Crucible tried to anchor the patch and presented us with the message seen in {{crc-2833_simple-patch-anchor-failure.png}} attached
# When we then selected the repo manually, Crucible went off for 30-45 seconds grabbing a list of the branches within the repo {{crc-2833_simple-patch-anchor-failure-2.png}}
# When we selected {{trunk}} for the repo in question, Crucible was able to anchor the patch {{crc-2833_simple-patch-anchor-failure-3.png}}

I guess I'm wondering why Crucible didn't check the default repo and path associated with the review project first? 
If it had, it should have been able to anchor straight away, without all the manual intervention.
fields.summary: Crucible does not use default repository and path when attempting to anchor a pre-commit patch

fields.description:
Description: Current HTTP headers do not contain the X-FRAME-Option, which helps prevents against Clickjacking attacks. A Clickjacking attack is similar to CSRF in which attacker can hijack a "click" on a web application from another "invisible" frame in the browser. Essentially, an attacker can force a user to click on a button that is invisible to him/her.

Exploit Scenario: An attacker crafts a malicious page such that when their victim clicks, they are actually clicking on the link or button in the vulnerable application hosted in an iframe. Thus, an attacker tricks the user into performing an action of the attacker's choosing by directing mouse input to the target application.

Short Term Solution: There are 2 options in the HTTP response header for projection, include:

DENY: If the header contains the DENY option, then the response will not be loaded within a frame.
SAMEORIGIN: If the header contains the SAMEORIGIN option, the response will be loaded within a frame only if the parent page is from the same origin.

Examples below:

Apache:
Add this to your httpd.conf:
Header always append x-frame-options SAMEORIGIN

Note that this is not a panacea for clickjacking.

SAMEORIGIN should be safe to use. See also [JST-5291|https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/JST-5291?focusedCommentId=47107&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-47107]
fields.summary: Enable X-FRAME-Option in HTTP response headers in order to improve clickjacking protection

fields.description:
h2.Problem
There is no bounds checking when mapping gutter comments to lines of code.
This means an entire review explodes with the following error, when the comments somehow don't match the lines in the file.
We should handle this more gracefully.

{code}
2011-07-13 23:57:34,151 ERROR [btpool0-6324 ] fisheye.app ViewFRXAction-execute - Problem creating FRXDO from frx
java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException: Index: 395, Size: 386
	at java.util.ArrayList.RangeCheck(ArrayList.java:547)
	at java.util.ArrayList.get(ArrayList.java:322)
	at com.cenqua.crucible.view.FRXDO.mapGutterComments(FRXDO.java:861)
	at com.cenqua.crucible.view.FRXDO.mapInlineComments(FRXDO.java:768)
	at com.cenqua.crucible.view.FRXDO.<init>(FRXDO.java:198)
	at com.cenqua.crucible.revision.managers.DefaultContentManager.makeFRXDO(DefaultContentManager.java:104)
	at com.atlassian.crucible.actions.ReviewBaseAction.makeFRXDO(ReviewBaseAction.java:596)
	at com.atlassian.crucible.actions.ViewFRXAction.execute(ViewFRXAction.java:184)
        ...
{code}

h2.Most probable reason
The root cause is not in line calculation algorithm, but in an inconsistent data store.
When users move/restore backup of Crucible instance incorrectly, we end up with DB out of sync with the files. This can result in db reusing unique file identifiers and Crucible overwriting a file in its cache. Where we used to have file A, now we have file B. Yet we still think we have file A. In effect, when we load a review for file A, we show contents of file B. If there has been a comment previously added to file A, say on line 395, and file B is only 386 lines long, we throw {{IndexOutOfBoundsException}} when we try to place that comment on file B.

h2.{color:red}*Workaround*{color}
(!) _This workaround will only work if the source repository is available and running. It will fail if repository is no longer available (including stopped/disabled) or the file originally came from an attachment._

On \*nix you can perform this fix while the instance is running (not sure about Windows).

h5. Find CFR number
Go to the file that doesn't load properly. {{CFR}} is displayed on the address bar after the '#'. Copy this number.

h5.SQL query to find the file names
Run the following query, substituting {{<CFR>}} with the number you have just copied:
{code:sql}SELECT
    r.cru_revision AS revision,
    r.cru_upload_item AS upload_item
FROM
    cru_frx_revision fr,
    cru_revision r
WHERE
    fr.cru_revision = r.cru_revision_id
AND fr.cru_frx_id = <CFR>
ORDER BY r.cru_upload_item{code}

h5.Delete cache files
The last column ({{upload_item}}) gives a list of cache file ids used to display this file (one per revision). Delete files named {{<upload_item>.dat}} from these folders:
* {{$FISHEYE_INST/var/tmp/encodedcontent/uploaditem}} 
* {{$FISHEYE_INST/var/data/uploads}} 

h5.Reload review page
Refresh the review +twice+. You should see the correct files loaded from the repository.

h2.Workaround - example
In my case the address bar shows {{http://localhost:8080/cru/CR-3#CFR-7}}, so {{CFR = 7}}. The SQL query returns

{noformat}revision upload_item 
-------- ----------- 
2000     19          
1999     20          
31       23          
30       24          
210      25          
211      26{noformat}

Then I look for these files:
{noformat}$ for CACHE_FOLDER in ./var/tmp/encodedcontent/uploaditem ./var/data/uploads/; do for UPLOAD_ITEM in 19 20 23 24 25 26 ; do find $CACHE_FOLDER -name $UPLOAD_ITEM.dat; done; done
./var/tmp/encodedcontent/uploaditem/00/00/19.dat
./var/tmp/encodedcontent/uploaditem/00/00/20.dat
./var/tmp/encodedcontent/uploaditem/00/00/23.dat
./var/tmp/encodedcontent/uploaditem/00/00/24.dat
./var/tmp/encodedcontent/uploaditem/00/00/25.dat
./var/tmp/encodedcontent/uploaditem/00/00/26.dat
./var/data/uploads//00/00/19.dat
./var/data/uploads//00/00/20.dat
./var/data/uploads//00/00/23.dat
./var/data/uploads//00/00/24.dat
./var/data/uploads//00/00/25.dat
./var/data/uploads//00/00/26.dat{noformat}

and delete all of them. Refresh browser twice and voilà!

h2.Proper fix
Rather than using consecutive numbers as file names, use their hash instead. When loading a file, check the hash matches. If not, invalidate the file store and pull the file from the repository.
fields.summary: Problem creating FRXDO from frx: Index: 395

fields.description:
At the moment it is only possible to specify one resolve issue transition id in Crucible and that transition id is used to resolve all sub-tasks that have been created from within Crucible.

Sub-tasks in different JIRA projects can be on differentw orkflows, and therefore the approach of specifying one transition id globally is not flexible enough.

We need to support multiple JIRA workflows such that it is possible to resolve sub-tasks no matter what workflow they are on.
fields.summary: Support multiple workflows for resolving sub-tasks that have been created from Crucible
The new HTML emails no longer provide a link directly to the thread of the message

fields.description:
At the moment teh id of the reoslution of JIRA issues is centrally configured in Crucible. So any issue resolved from Crucible will take the configured resolution.

Often it would be useful to customise which resolution to give the issue as the issue is being resolved.
fields.summary: Allow to specify the resolution of the issue when resolving it from within Crucible

fields.description:
Hi, 

i'm not sure of this is fixed already - but one of my colleague Chris has analyzed this problem.

Can you please look into and perhaps comment on these findings and the actions we took.  it is it ok to delete the way we did?  what options do we have - or is this a code fix on your side? have you already fixed this in a version > 2.5.3?

thx

Chris:

Crucible has a Hibernate audit interceptor which inserts rows into the cru_feindex_msg table when a review gets touched, to ask Fisheye to reindex files relating to the modified code review asynchronously. The indexer thread deletes rows from this table immediately after indexing. The table is effectively a messaging queue containing temporary data.

The code which consumes from this table is in ReviewInfoDao.doIncremental(). This loads all the rows from the cru_feindex_msg table then iterates over them in a transaction. Every time a Hibernate flush occurs during processing, it does a dirty check of all the objects in the session. If you double the number of items in the cru_feindex_msg table, that means you're processing twice as many items and for each item the Hibernate session is doing twice as many dirty checks: the result is O(N^2) performance.

Unfortunately treasury-svn currently has 268,000 items pending indexing in the cru_feindex_msg table, and the indexer has made no progress on this at all today as far as I can tell. The table includes over 200K rows relating to 3 astoundingly large commits. I think these happened when someone accidentally deleted the SVN trunk and then restored it.

select r.cru_revision_display_name, count(*)
from cru_feindex_msg m, cru_revision r, cru_stored_path p
where  m.cru_fr_id = r.cru_revision_id
and r.cru_path = p.cru_path_id
and r.cru_source_name = 'treasury-svn'
group by  r.cru_revision_display_name
order by 2 desc

cru_revision_display_name     count    
 ----------------------------  -------- 
 55022                         71147    
 55316                         69664    
 55315                         69664    
 63040                         7330     
 63354                         2108     
 63346                         2108     
...

Do you or Atlassian have any suggestions how we can fix this? Would re-indexing the repository from scratch help? In the short term I suspect deleting these 3 problematic commit revisions (200K rows) from the cru_feindex_msg working table is likely to help the indexer recover, but I'd want to check first that there are unlikely to be side effects.
 
Thanks,
Chris

PS. It's possible that this has happened recently because a developer did something to touch an old code review containing these change sets - maybe they closed it? We did start asking developers about a week ago to be good and close their old reviews. Circumstantial evidence at best.


•	svn commit 55022 was someone copying a historical revision of the trunk back to the head of the trunk after accidentally deleting it.
•	55315 was someone copying the contents of /trunk into /trunk/trunk
•	55316 was that developer deleting the accidental copy

For the first time that I've seen in weeks or months, treasury-svn no longer says it is busy indexing our reviews. To let the indexer catch up I pruned some rows from cru_feindex_msg. This contains the list of reviews and file revisions which have been requested to be reindexed asynchronously. Items get inserted into this table every time the review changes.

Delete duplicated requests to reindex reviews from cru_feindex_msg:

select m1.cru_id
from cru_feindex_msg m1
    left join cru_review r on m1.cru_review_id = r.cru_review_id
    join cru_feindex_msg m2 on m1.cru_review_id = m2.cru_review_id and m1.cru_fr_id = m2.cru_fr_id
where m1.cru_id < m2.cru_id
and   r.cru_project = 13 (13 is treasury)

Delete requests to reindex reviews which are already closed or dead:

select m.cru_id
from cru_feindex_msg m
left join cru_review r on r.cru_review_id = m.cru_review_id
where r.cru_state in ( 'Closed', 'Dead')
and   r.cru_project = 13

Then you can check which projects have a big backlog of files remaining to be reindexed:

select r.cru_source_name, count(*)
from cru_feindex_msg m, cru_revision r
where  m.cru_fr_id = r.cru_revision_id
group by r.cru_source_name
order by 2 desc

cru_source_name     count    
 ------------------  -------- 
 middle-office-svn   20269    
 HydraSVN            6398     

Treasury previously had 260,000. The above deletions reduced this to about 20,000, and that backlog got cleared in a few hours.

The middle-office-svn count doesn't seem to have decreased much since I've been looking at it. Probably some big items to reindex in there?

It may have been possible to achieve the same just by asking Fisheye to reindex the project from scratch - this deletes the contents of cru_feindex_msg which is only used for incremental indexing - but I wasn't brave enough to trust that this wouldn't make Crucible unavailable to us for several days.

fields.description:
From: https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/JST-5072

{quote}
To reproduce:
1. Use Chrome
2. Sign in to StAC and go to review [CR-JST-599|https://studio.atlassian.com/source/cru/CR-JST-599], which has a general comment
3. Click the cursor in the quick search box and start typing 'tim'
4. Only 't' is in the search box; 'i' and 'm' seem to be Crucible hotkeys. You can actually observe that when 'm' is pressed, the comment is toggled between read/unread.
{quote}

I've had a look into this. Crucible is binding key events to {{document}} in keynav.js but events {{return false}} which means {{event.stopPropogation()}} and {{event.preventDefault()}} to jQuery. We probably only want to stop propagation.

Maybe a solution is to explicitly call {{event.stopPropagation()}} instead of returning false.
fields.summary: Keystrokes keyed in Studio's quick search box are captured by Crucible

fields.description:
Our review indexing gets stuck on some repos and we have to bounce crucible (deleting $FECRU/var/cache/theStuckRepo helps for a week or so) for it to detect recent commits.  It would be useful to allow this to happen in their own threads so they don't block each other.  This means devs/release managers don't see commits against jira issues, and "lose the tooling" just when they need it most - when trying to release software.

This is a good idea independent of our problem with review index hangs.  I've discussed this with Geoff at Atlas Summit.
fields.summary: Revision scanning and Review indexing should happen in independent threads

Adding a changeset to a review from the changeset dialog, when the changeset has never been added before to another review via the activity stream, will cause the line count for the file revision in the changeset to be wrong. This shows up in a rest request (but not the UI) - see the {{<changedLines>}} field below - should be 3, but is 1 for some of the revisions. 

To reproduce:

fields.summary: The line counts (<changedLines> field in the rest api) for a review item is incorrect if that file revision is added via the changeset browser

fields.description: As a reviewer, go to a review, have another reviewer join, but not comment. Don't refresh the page, just click 'Complete' -- you'll be told that the review has changed and you'll need to refresh before you can complete. This is sensible if there are new comments, but is it sensible if there are just new reviewers?
fields.summary: Addition of a reviewer shouldn't be a change to a review from the POV of completing the review

fields.description:
mstudman: review history timeline entries overlap https://img.skitch.com/20110317-ng52mjjqirfbydkkh42sjaek3f.jpg

!https://img.skitch.com/20110317-ng52mjjqirfbydkkh42sjaek3f.jpg!
fields.summary: [IE9] Review history timeline entries overlap
Creating review from empty merge commit sets title and author, but has no link to the changeset

fields.description:
A Javascript appears in the Firebug console when adding a linked review to an existing one.

However it does not seem to impact the user, as it is neither visible in the UI nor preventing the review to be added (nor it prevents to the popup with the review description to be shown).

After quickly checking it, it seems to be a bug in JQuery's autocomplete plugin. Would be good to have some JS expert looks at it.

(see attached screen capture).
fields.summary: Linking review throws JavaScript errors

fields.description:
If it is possible to link tortoisehg to crucible it will make the review creation faster( you will not have to create a manual diff file, connect to the review server, create a review request etc... )

Actualy toirtoisehg link with an other review tool reviewBoard (http://www.reviewboard.org).
After a commit, reviewBoard prompt a gui when you can create the review, add instruction, select review group. Also, the diff file is generated and uploaded automatically.

There is an overview of the actual gui [here|http://www.mikeyd.com.au/projects/tortoisehg-reviewboard/]
fields.summary: Integration with tortoiseHg to create precommit reviews

fields.description: When a user leaves a changeset comment, particularly a defect I would like to create a JIRA issue directly from FishEye so that I can track the issue. Otherwise the changeset comment is liable to be forgotten or ignored, as I need to leave it in my email or write it on a sticky note.
fields.summary: Allow me to create a JIRA issue from a Changeset Comment

fields.description:
Via a user at Summit:

"When we synch with Crowd and a user is flagged as deactivated in Crowd, 
they are not being removed as a Crucible user. We want that users data to stick around for auditing, however we need to free up licenses when people leave the company."

This could require a new option on synching with how to deal with deactivated users in crowd.

Current behaviour is possibly the user becomes 'deleted' from Crucible/FishEye when they are deactivated from Crowd. This needs testing/investigation though.
fields.summary: Improve synching of deactivated users in Crucible

fields.description: I've just discovered that other people, aside from just me, delete all their Crucible emails as they come in and only use them as a flag to say they need to check Crucible. It would be good to get these emails as a digest at hourly or daily intervals, rather than as frequently as they are now.
fields.summary: Digest emails for Crucible

fields.description:
Hello.

This issue is reproducible on FireFox 4.0, Internet Explorer 8.0.7600.16385, and Google Chrome 11.0.696.77.

If you open a review, click on any file being reviewed on the left, and click on the button *Toggle fullscreen mode ('shift+f')* below the avatar image, the menus *Edit Details*, *Summarize* and *Tools* will hover the dropdowns *FishEye* and *File Outdated* displayed below them while not in fullscreen.

Please see the attachments for more details.
fields.summary: "Edit Details", "Summarize" and "Tools" menus hover error on fullscreen mode
